title: Appendix A — Draft: Data Documentation
text:
https://www.spc.noaa.gov/wcm/data/SPC_severe_database_description.pdf

library(tidyverse)

tornado_full_data <- read.csv("1950-2024_actual_tornadoes.csv")

tornado_data <- tornado_full_data |>
  select(yr, date, st, mag, slat, slon, elat, elon, len, wid, ns, sn, sg)

tornado_data_counted_once <- tornado_data |>
  filter(sn == 0) |>
  select(-ns,-sn,-sg) |>
  arrange(date)









Tornado Data Variable Descriptions


Variable Name
Description
Type
Possible Values




yr
Year Tornado Occurred
Integer
1950-2024


date
Exact Date Tornado Occurred
Date
01-01-1950 to 12/31/2024


st
State Abbreviation Where Tornado First Touched Down
Categorical
Any US State


mag
EF Scale Magnitude of the Tornado
Integer
0-5 or -9 Meaning Unknown


slat
Latitude Where the Tornado First Touched Down
Numeric
US Latitudes ~ 29 to 50


slon
Longitude Where the Tornado First Touched Down
Numeric
US Longitudes ~ -125 to -70


elat
Latitude Where the Tornado Ended
Numeric
US Latitudes ~ 29 to 50


elon
Longitude Where the Tornado Ended
Numeric
US Longitudes ~ -125 to -70


len
Tornado Path Length (Miles)
Numeric
0-250 Miles


wid
Tornado Path Width (Yards)
Numeric
0-3500 Yards







The data were collected by NOAA National Weather Prediction Service.
The data was collected simply for the purpose of historical records and public safety, so that there can be research into these tornadoes.
The data is about tornadoes, showing where they occur and how they travel.
The data was collected from 1950-2024, and shows the date each tornado occurred as a column in the dataset.
The data was collected all around the United States. This includes (potentially) all states.
Reports from storm spotters and what the NWS considers reputable sources are submitted to the Storm Data publication by National Weather Service field offices.
The data is a simple CSV file with each row representing one tornado and each column being a different descriptor of the tornado.
The NOAA is a reputable known source for these types of data so there should be no data quality issues.
Some suggested data analysis methods include probability estimation based on magnitude and/or distance travelled inland or towards the coast

title: 1  Introduction
text:
This is a book created from markdown and executable code.
See Knuth (1984) for additional discussion of literate programming.




Knuth, Donald E. 1984. “Literate Programming.” Comput. J. 27 (2): 97–111. https://doi.org/10.1093/comjnl/27.2.97.

title: 2  Summary
text: In summary, this book has no content whatsoever.
